question_text: A 28-year-old woman with acute pharyngitis develops a rapidly expanding diffuse rash. The rash (shown) has a sandpaper-like texture.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is scarlet fever (Option C), which refers to the syndrome of an erythematous rash that occurs in association with Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis. The rash is a diffuse blanching rash consisting of 1- to 2-mm papules that give the rash a unique sandpaper-like texture when palpated. The rash begins and is most marked in the groin and axillae and then rapidly spreads to the trunk and extremities. Most patients have characteristic circumoral pallor and sparing of the palms and soles. Strawberry tongue may also be present.
